solution: For the piecewise function to be continuous, the cases must "meet" at $2$ and $-2$. For example, $ax+3$ and $x-5$ must be equal when $x=2$. This implies $a(2)+3=2-5$, which we solve to get $2a=-6 \Rightarrow a=-3$. Similarly, $x-5$ and $2x-b$ must be equal when $x=-2$. Substituting, we get $-2-5=2(-2)-b$, which implies $b=3$. So $a+b=-3+3=\boxed{0}$.

To find $a+b$, we need to ensure the function is continuous at $x = 2$ and $x = -2$. 

First step: Evaluate the left and right-hand limits of $f(x)$ at $x = 2$: 
$$\lim_{x \to 2^-} f(x) = \lim_{x \to 2^-} (x - 5) = 2 - 5 = -3$$ 
$$\lim_{x \to 2^+} f(x) = \lim_{x \to 2^+} (ax + 3) = 2a + 3$$
Since the function is continuous at $x = 2$, we have $\lim_{x \to 2^-} f(x) = \lim_{x \to 2^+} f(x)$. So, $-3 = 2a + 3$. Solving for $a$ gives $a = -3$.

Second step: Evaluate the left and right-hand limits of $f(x)$ at $x = -2$: 
$$\lim_{x \to -2^+} f(x) = \lim_{x \to -2^+} (x - 5) = -2 - 5 = -7$$ 
$$\lim_{x \to -2^-} f(x) = \lim_{x \to -2^-} (2x - b) = -4 - b$$
Since the function is continuous at $x = -2$, we have $\lim_{x \to -2^-} f(x) = \lim_{x \to -2^+} f(x)$. So, $-4 - b = -7$. Solving for $b$ gives $b = 3$.
